Wobblies timeline

Inspired and sourced from the graphic novel: Wobblies! A Graphic History of the Industrial Workers of the World, which features a different comic artist for each subject/era, and also by colly.com's timeline, this page tells the story from each of the famous labor union's prominent figures.

What struck me was each artist's unique tribute to the legendary fighters. To not let them drip from my mind sieve, I snapped photos as a way to help remember their stories, before returning the book to library.

  • 1905

    The Industrial Workers of the World (IWW), the Wobblies, was formed in Chicago. They represent the working class With a focus direct action.

    At one time they had 100k members in the US and 10k+ worldwide. They aim to unite all workers, regardless of skill level or trade, into one big union to overthrow capitalism and establish a more just society.

  • 1886

    Lucy Parsons was a founding member of the IWW. Parsons was a powerful speaker and organizer, fighting for the rights of workers, women, and people of color. She was a key figure in the Haymarket Riot of 1886, and continued to fight for social justice until her death in 1942. Her activism led to the execution of four labor organizers and sparked international May Day celebrations.

    "Let us all labor to add one more word to the preamble of the constitution, and that word is 'industrial.'"

  • 1911

    The Magón Brothers were journalists and activists who played a key role in the founding of the IWW in Mexico. 1911, published "Regeneración" and became leading voices in the Mexican anarchist movement.

    "All the tyrannies of which the working class is victim are born of the government and capitalism. The government is the head of the monster; capitalism is its body."

  • 1912

    Mother Jones was an Irish-American labor organizer and founding member. Jones was known as the "most dangerous woman in America," and was a tireless fighter for workers' rights. She was also a key figure in the United Mine Workers of America. She led a children's march to the home of President Theodore Roosevelt to demand better working conditions for miners in 1912.

    "Pray for the dead and fight like hell for the living."

  • 1912

    "Big" Bill Haywood was another founding member. His leadership played a crucial role in several successful strikes and campaigns, such as the 1912 Bread and Roses strike, which saw over 20,000 textile workers in Lawrence, MA strike for better wages and working conditions. He was known for his fiery speeches, which helped the IWW grow to be a powerful force in the labor movement.

    "The mine owners did not find the gold, they did not mine the gold, they did not mill the gold, but by some weird alchemy, all the gold belonged to them."

  • 1914

    Mabel Dodge, a wealthy socialite, becomes involved in labor activism after attending an IWW meeting. She uses her influence to support the labor movement. In 1914 she helped organize the Paterson silk strike in New Jersey.

    "The economic freedom of women is necessary to free our civilization from the tyranny of the patriarchal family."

  • 1915

    Joe Hill organized and led a strike of dock workers in San Pedro, CA 1915. Swedish-American who wrote many songs that become popular among labor unions, including "The Preacher and the Slave" and "There is Power in a Union."

    "A pamphlet, no matter how good, is never read more than once. But a song is learned by heart and repeated over and over."

  • 1916

    Frank Little. In 1916, he was appointed as the IWW's national field secretary and was tasked with organizing workers in the west. He played a key role in organizing the Mesabi Range miners strike that year, which was one of the largest strikes in American history.

    Little's dedication to labor rights and his commitment to nonviolent protest made him a target for the authorities. Known for his uncompromising spirit and refusal to back down in the face of opposition, he faced threats, violence, and imprisonment, but never wavered in his commitment to the cause.

    "Workers of the world, awaken! Break your chains, demand your rights. All the wealth you produce belongs to you, not to a minority of parasites."

  • 1920

    Elizabeth Gurley Flynn joins the IWW at just 16, and quickly rose to a most effective organizers. She was a trailblazer, as she was one of the few women who held leadership positions in the labor movement during her time, and she was also one of the few who openly embraced socialism.

    She was a passionate advocate on the Defense Committee for the Italian-born American anarchists Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti, who were convicted and ultimately executed for a robbery and murder they may not have committed in 1920.

    "We are all born free and equal, but some are more equal than others."

  • 1932

    "T-Bone" Slim Brundage was an traveling worker who wrote songs and poems promoting the IWW message, eventually influencing Kerouak and Ginsburg.

    In 1932 he helped organize the National Hunger March in D.C., in response to high levels of unemployment and poverty that were plaguing the country. Although it was met with violence from the police, it brought attention to the struggles of workers during the Great Depression.

    "The only good scab is a dead scab." BETTER

  • 1937

    Paul Robeson was known for his powerful baritone voice and his ability to convey a deep sense of emotion through his singing. He brought new life to Joe Hill's labor anthems.

    In 1937 he played a crucial role in setting up the Council on African Affairs - an organization aimed at promoting African liberation at a time when such issues received little attention from Americans. He inspired countless civil rights and labor activists, including Angela Davis and Harry Belafonte.

    "The artist must take sides. He must elect to fight for freedom or for slavery. I have made my choice."

  • 1915

    Emma Goldman becomes involved in the movement after working in a factory in Rochester, NY while experiencing harsh working conditions and mistreatment. Her fiery rhetoric draws her toward newspaper contributions and speaking events.

    In 1915, she started a lecture tour in which she advocated for women's access to birth control, a topic that was taboo at the time. She remained an influential figure in the birth control movement until her death in 1940. She was arrested several times for participation in strikes, and eventually deported from the US for her beliefs.

    "The most violent element in society is ignorance."

  • 1965

    Gary Snyder, a prominent anarchist and labor activist, becomes involved with the IWW and gives speeches on behalf of the organization. 1965, participated in the Delano grape strike and became a leading voice in the environmental and counter-cultural movements.

    "The most violent element in society is ignorance."

  • 1989

    Judi Bari, an environmental and labor activist, is injured when a bomb explodes in her car in Oakland, California. Despite being targeted for her activism, she is later falsely accused by the FBI of being responsible for the bombing. In 1989 she organized a successful campaign to save California's Headwaters Forest from logging.

    "The only way we can stop the destruction of the Earth and its people is to build alliances. And the only way to build alliances is to be honest and respectful with each other."
